title: American Standard Code for Information Interchange

|                                                   | [Zz](/wiki/Z "Z")                                                                  | [Xx](/wiki/X "X")                                                                  | [Cc](/wiki/C "C")                                                                  | [Vv](/wiki/V "V")                                                                  | [Bb](/wiki/B "B")                                                                  | [Nn](/wiki/N "N")  | [Mm](/wiki/M "M")  | [,](/wiki/, ",")  | [.](/wiki/Dot "Dot") | [/](/wiki/Slash "Slash") | [<](/wiki/Angle_bracket "Angle bracket") | [>](/wiki/Angle_bracket "Angle bracket") |                 [Alt](/wiki/Alt "Alt")                |                                                         |                                   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |

The **American Standard Code for Information Interchange**, normally abbreviated **ASCII**, is a [character set](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/character_set "wikipedia:character set") which a computer uses to store **characters**. ASCII specifies a method for computers to store printable characters such as letters A to Z, a to z, digits 0 to 9, punctuation, and spaces. ASCII also includes control characters such as newline. Most computers either use ASCII, or a superset of ASCII that adds more characters, such as accented letters, Cyrillic letters, CJK characters, or hieroglyphics.

*[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")* uses ASCII for everything. The [source code](/wiki/Source_code "Source code") is in ASCII. If you play in [tty](/wiki/Tty "Tty") mode (without [DECgraphics](/wiki/DECgraphics "DECgraphics"), [IBMgraphics](/wiki/IBMgraphics "IBMgraphics"), or color), everything on the screen is ASCII. Also, ASCII corresponds nicely with the keys found on most [QWERTY keyboards](/wiki/Keyboard "Keyboard") in the United States. In fact, in modern NetHack 3.x.x, the [dungeon](/wiki/Dungeon "Dungeon") contains every printable ASCII character except "6", "7", "8", and "9"; "," (the comma) appears only on the [Rogue level](/wiki/Rogue_level "Rogue level"). Some older versions of NetHack did use "8" for [Medusa](/wiki/Medusa "Medusa") and "9" for [giants](/wiki/Giant "Giant"), but [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0") made monster symbols refer to classes of monsters rather than necessarily single monsters, and now Medusa is @ and giants are H.

The characters in the table to the right link to their informational page. The goal is to create an article in [NetHackWiki](/wiki/NetHackWiki "NetHackWiki") for every character. In the article, mention which [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") or [object](/wiki/Object "Object") that character represents, and what that key does from the keyboard. Try to link to other articles; for example, [d](/wiki/D "D") should link to both [dog](/wiki/Dog "Dog") and [drop](/wiki/Drop "Drop").

NetHack also uses some non-printable ASCII characters for commands. Those are commands that use [Ctrl](/wiki/Ctrl "Ctrl") key. Pressing [Ctrl](/wiki/Ctrl "Ctrl") and another character sends a non-printable character. [Alt](/wiki/Alt "Alt") key has similar function.

For technical reasons, [angle brackets](/wiki/Angle_bracket "Angle bracket"), [curly brackets](/wiki/Curly_bracket "Curly bracket"), [square brackets](/wiki/Square_bracket "Square bracket"), [hash marks](/wiki/Hash_mark "Hash mark"), [pipes](/wiki/Pipe "Pipe"), or [plus signs](/wiki/Plus_sign "Plus sign") can not be used in the names of articles. Also, an article name cannot contain only [underscores](/wiki/Underscore "Underscore"), and it cannot consist of exactly one or two [dots](/wiki/Dot "Dot"). Thus all of those articles have words for names.

## See also

- [Options#color](/wiki/Options#color "Options")

[![This article is unlikely to require revision for the next version of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/58/Noversion.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article is unlikely to require revision for the next version of NetHack. Click here for more information.")
html:
American Standard Code for Information Interchange

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Wikipedia has an article about:
ASCII
Printable ASCII characters
~ ! @ # $ % ^ & * ( ) _ + space
` 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 0 - = { } |
Qq Ww Ee Rr Tt Yy Uu Ii Oo Pp : " [ ] \
Aa Ss Dd Ff Gg Hh Jj Kk Ll ? ; ' Ctrl
Zz Xx Cc Vv Bb Nn Mm , . / < > Alt

The American Standard Code for Information Interchange, normally abbreviated ASCII, is a character set which a computer uses to store characters. ASCII specifies a method for computers to store printable characters such as letters A to Z, a to z, digits 0 to 9, punctuation, and spaces. ASCII also includes control characters such as newline. Most computers either use ASCII, or a superset of ASCII that adds more characters, such as accented letters, Cyrillic letters, CJK characters, or hieroglyphics.

NetHack uses ASCII for everything. The source code is in ASCII. If you play in tty mode (without DECgraphics, IBMgraphics, or color), everything on the screen is ASCII. Also, ASCII corresponds nicely with the keys found on most QWERTY keyboards in the United States. In fact, in modern NetHack 3.x.x, the dungeon contains every printable ASCII character except "6", "7", "8", and "9"; "," (the comma) appears only on the Rogue level. Some older versions of NetHack did use "8" for Medusa and "9" for giants, but NetHack 3.0.0 made monster symbols refer to classes of monsters rather than necessarily single monsters, and now Medusa is @ and giants are H.

The characters in the table to the right link to their informational page. The goal is to create an article in NetHackWiki for every character. In the article, mention which monster or object that character represents, and what that key does from the keyboard. Try to link to other articles; for example, d should link to both dog and drop.

NetHack also uses some non-printable ASCII characters for commands. Those are commands that use Ctrl key. Pressing Ctrl and another character sends a non-printable character. Alt key has similar function.

For technical reasons, angle brackets, curly brackets, square brackets, hash marks, pipes, or plus signs can not be used in the names of articles. Also, an article name cannot contain only underscores, and it cannot consist of exactly one or two dots. Thus all of those articles have words for names.

See also

  • Options#color

rawPage:
{{wikipedia|ASCII}}
{{ASCII}}
The '''American Standard Code for Information Interchange''', normally abbreviated '''ASCII''', is a [[Wikipedia:character set|character set]] which a computer uses to store '''characters'''. ASCII specifies a method for computers to store printable characters such as letters A to Z, a to z, digits 0 to 9, punctuation, and spaces. ASCII also includes control characters such as newline. Most computers either use ASCII, or a superset of ASCII that adds more characters, such as accented letters, Cyrillic letters, CJK characters, or hieroglyphics.

''[[NetHack]]'' uses ASCII for everything. The [[source code]] is in ASCII. If you play in [[tty]] mode (without [[DECgraphics]], [[IBMgraphics]], or color), everything on the screen is ASCII. Also, ASCII corresponds nicely with the keys found on most [[keyboard|QWERTY keyboards]] in the United States. In fact, in modern NetHack 3.x.x, the [[dungeon]] contains every printable ASCII character except "6", "7", "8", and "9"; "," (the comma) appears only on the [[Rogue level]]. Some older versions of NetHack did use "8" for [[Medusa]] and "9" for [[giant]]s, but [[NetHack 3.0.0]] made monster symbols refer to classes of monsters rather than necessarily single monsters, and now Medusa is @ and giants are H.

The characters in the table to the right link to their informational page. The goal is to create an article in [[NetHackWiki]] for every character. In the article, mention which [[monster]] or [[object]] that character represents, and what that key does from the keyboard. Try to link to other articles; for example, [[d]] should link to both [[dog]] and [[drop]].

NetHack also uses some non-printable ASCII characters for commands. Those are commands that use {{kbd|Ctrl}} key. Pressing {{kbd|Ctrl}} and another character sends a non-printable character. {{kbd|Alt}} key has similar function.

For technical reasons, [[angle bracket]]s, [[curly bracket]]s, [[square bracket]]s, [[hash mark]]s, [[pipe]]s, or [[plus sign]]s can not be used in the names of articles. Also, an article name cannot contain only [[underscore]]s, and it cannot consist of exactly one or two [[dot]]s. Thus all of those articles have words for names.

==See also==
* [[Options#color]]
